entry.title: Paropsisterna nigerrima
entry.content: This dark beetle is Paropsisterna nigerrima var. picta. The structure is identical to the common striped form but the color pattern is different. The important srtuctural feature to note for ID is the fine striae (puncturation lines) along the elytra. Sadly, the color patterns are no help. The third variety (nigerrima nigerrima) is entirely black. I suspect that at least two more variations occur that are not recorded in the MOV collection. One is entirely light and dark banded, the other is from NSW and has a different red spot pattern.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: I do not know this species of Paropsisterna. This leaf beetle is quite common and I have seen it in many parts of Victoria.

entry.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
entry.content: A very common leaf beetle with rows of beading or marbling along the striae of the elytra. The body and legs are always black. The insect is sometimes brown. green, red, orange, yellow or entirely black. The pronotum is typically patterned with a clear patch either side of the centre line.

entry.title: Trachymela sloanei
entry.content: A brown convex beetle with black bumbs ober the elytra.

entry.title: Trachymela spp.
entry.content: A new and unknown species of Trachymela

entry.title: Peltoschema maculiventris
entry.content: This beetle is Peltoschema maculoventris. It is more heavily marked than Peltoschema hamadryas and generally the black markings are entirely joined

entry.title: Peltoschema tetraspilota
entry.content: Peltoschema tetraspilota is a four spotted leaf beetle found quite scarcely on acacia. I have found it only on silver wattle.

entry.title: Peltoschema hamadryas
entry.content: This beetle was found on silver wattle. The patterns are quite variable. I do not think it occurs in the same large numbers as the fireblight beetle P. orphana. The larva is yellow and appears in another spotting. A yellow larva is certainly a flower feeder.

entry.title: Peltoschema perplexa
entry.content: This is Peltoschema perplexa in its pale form. Many leaf beetles can appear in a green form or a yellow form or anywhere in between. For the purposes of identification, the markings on the elytra are most reliable.

entry.title: Peltoschema orphana
entry.content: Peltoschema orphana is the most common leaf beetle found on Acacia, usually silver wattle. Commonly called the fireblight beetle it can cause devastation to silver wattle populations and even kill trees by defoliation. This versatile little beast is polyphagus and was feeding, with several others, and their larvae, on Eucalyptus which is uncommon but has been recorded before.

entry.title: Peltoschema perplexa
entry.content: This beetle is Peltoschema perplexa. I have determined this by comparison of its consistent pattern with the museum of Victoria collection. This beetle seems to be scarce and I have seen it only twice. Peltoschema is a genus of Acacia feeders and this one seems to occur on the small leafed wattle illustrated. Maybe someone knows the species. Christmas Hills has a population of these wattles and we found many beetles that day

entry.title: Peltoschema pandora
entry.content: This is Peltoschema pandora. Small, scarce and illustrated already on ALA website.

entry.title: Peltoschema oceanica
entry.content: This leaf beetle is vegetarian but easily mistaken for its mimicry model, the carnivorous spotted ladybird beetle. This one is sometimes mis-identified in photographic images and pinned collections. Leaf beetles have long antennae and ladybirds are very short and slightly knobbed in that department. This beetle has four pronotal spots (usually) and once you notice this, you will hardly be fooled by this devious copycat beetle.

entry.title: Peltoschema suturalis
entry.content: The larvae of Peltoschema suturalis feed on broad leafed Acacia. These were found on Golden Wattle.

entry.title: Paropsisterna crocata
entry.content: Paropsisterna crocata This pale green beetle stayed for two photos and was gone. The one I saw last year flew away before I could lift my camera. This uncommon beetle occurs in a range of pale and subtle colors. Kilsyth; Chirnside Park and Eltham North; http://user-generated-content.natureshare.org.au/observations/photos/x1024/53b7f028e35eb16e5a00003f.JPG?1404563553

entry.title: Paropsisterna crocata
entry.content: Paropsisterna crocata. The pale green or peachy tan (in this case) monotone color on this large and handsome beetle is very distinctive. It is certainly among the largest of all Paropsisterna and seldom encountered. This has been recorded in Canberra also. See another in Eltham North; http://user-generated-content.natureshare.org.au/observations/photos/x1024/53b7f028e35eb16e5a00003f.JPG?1404563553

entry.title: Paropsisterna nucea
entry.content: Paropsisterna nucea is a common nitid (glossy) honey-brown leaf beetle. It does occur in a pale form and might have black markings on the pronotum. I have seen these at Mt Donna Buang, Kinglake, Eildon, Licola.

entry.title: Paropsisterna nucea
entry.content: This specimen is a pale form of P. nucea which is more commonly a honey-brown color with lighter lateral margins.

entry.title: Paropsisterna pictipes
entry.content: This pale beetle is a variation of the usual color of pale green and pink/red.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: This beetle is possibly Paropsisterna decolorate. The elytral patterns differ somewhat and I can determine if this is differeny .

entry.title: Paropsisterna m-fuscum
entry.content: Paropsisterna m-fuscum is a small beetle with a variable brown and blue/grey pattern on the elytra. A light flare often occurs at the base of the elytra. This species is sometimes a pest to eucalyptus plantations, particularly where they have been introduced into other countries.

entry.title: Paropsis spp.
entry.content: This is Paropsis but undetermined.

entry.title: Paropsis roseola
entry.content: Paropsis roseola. This beetle is scarce and appears to occur in the Western deserts and further west to Perth. This beetle is identified by and named for its pink pronotum.

entry.title: Dicranosterna immaculata
entry.content: The distinctive larva of the acacia leaf beetle Dicranosterna immaculata.

entry.title: Dicranosterna immaculata
entry.content: A dark lead beetle with red skirt , head and suture. The larva is quite distinct and illustrated also.

entry.title: Paropsisterna lignea
entry.content: This variable species is Paropsisterna lignea. It may have three dots on the pronotum and be strongly lined or entirely unlined elytra. It seems to be common in alpine habitats. There are interstitial puncturations (pitting between the rows of grooves) of random positioning but of equal size as the striae puncturations. (see close-up.)

entry.title: Paropsisterna agricola
entry.content: Paropsisterna agricola occasionally shows off with a bright red skirt.

entry.title: Paropsisterna agricola
entry.content: This beetle is named Paropsisterna agricola. It is common in Tasmania it can become an agricultural pest. The pale skirt can be bright red in some specimens. This species is determined by the black markings on the pronotum and the elytra with some flaring at the base.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: Paropsisterna sp. This bright green beetle has variable red on the shoulders and sometimes covering the entire elytra. There is some red across the head and sometimes extending through the pronotum. Seen in Wonga Park, Glenburn and Eildon. Also in Tasmania. I have, on suggestion removed the P. laesa title as this beetle has striae puncturations in very regular lines and laesa is very irregular in its pattern as seen in the pinned specimen of laesa.

entry.title: Calomela maculicollis
entry.content: This is Calomela maculicollis. A widespread species of acacia leaf beetle identified by being broad and having three dots on the pronotum. There are sensory bristles on the corners of the pronotum and these can be folded away when not needed. They are very hard to see but are the determining feature for identifying the Calomela genus.

entry.title: Trachymela spp.
entry.content: A large leaf beetle with red base color and black marks on the elytra.

entry.title: Trachymela rugosa
entry.content: Trachymela rugosa. A warty leaf beetle with meandering lines forming a complex pattern over the elytra. There remain two spots uncovered on the shoulders of the elytra forming two dots.

entry.title: Trachymela sloanei
entry.content: Trachymela spp. A black beetle with neat rows of tubercles and a fine coating of white powder.

entry.title: Trachymela spp.
entry.content: A small undetermined species of Trachymela

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: This is another Paropsisterna from the interlita group. I am not sure yet how they fit together and which species is which. This appears to be diurnal. I saw this also at Aberfeldy.

entry.title: Paropsisterna intacta
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsisterna intacta. A very rotund and large leaf beetle found under bark. I have seen these a dozen times and they are considered common. I have never seen them except under bark. They seem to prefer smooth (white) barked eucalyptus with large leaves.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna spp. It belongs in the interlita group but not sure the species. It looks like one that Russel Best has photographed in his lawn. http://natureshare.org.au/observations/53b3985ae35eb12984010d2c?species=Paropsisterna+spp.&tag= It is related to Paropsisterna intacta, an under bark nocturnal species. It features foveae (small dimples) in the sides of the pronotum, emphasized in this case by a black dot. I have seen this only once before at Taggerty on a small shrub. Found on a messmate eucalyptus. Seems to be diurnal

entry.title: Paropsisterna decolorata
entry.content: This colorful beetle is very variable. There is a pattern on the pronotum which contains the impression of a 'u' or horseshoe. There is often flaring from the base of the elytra which can make bright patterns. The white markings along the striae are larger and stronger than for variicollis.

entry.title: Paropsisterna decolorata
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna decolorata and shows a more common variety with strong white beading, lines and 'u' pattern on the pronotum and flaring from the base of the elytra.

entry.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
entry.content: A very common leaf beetle with rows of beading or marbling along the striae of the elytra. The body and legs are always black. The insect is sometimes brown. green, red, orange, yellow or entirely black. The pronotum is typically patterned with a clear patch either side of the centre line.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: I have no ID to offer for this species. It has definite similarities with P. atalanta which is mottled red but with the same black regions and found in the same location. I have seen this only once

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: This beetle is small and green with a somewhat constant pattern of red zone along the elytra usually laterally and usually leaving a green stripe dorsally. The pronotum is green and usually unmarked or weakly marked with white patterns. I suspect this is might be P. obovata but lack confidence in this designation.

entry.title: Paropsisterna pictipes
entry.content: This species looks like Paropsis but is Paropsisterna pictipes, A pale green leaf beetle with pink trim along the edges of the elytra and suture. The puncturations are strong and random and with no indication of striae, as might be expected for paropsis. Seen once only. Montane.

entry.title: Paropsisterna erudita
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsis erudita. It is a highly nitid (glossy) species found under bark of smooth barked eucalyptus spp. such as manna gum. This is the more scarce of the nocturnal leaf beetles in my experience and found only twice. Also seen at Wonga Park (Mt Lofty) and Healesville. It lacks striae grooves and puncturation is very fine. There are two very smart looking red diagonal lines on the combined elytra in the form of a chevron.

entry.title: Paropsisterna morio
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsisterna morio. It was found under bark of manna gum. It is entirely black sometimes with brown or lighter lines in the interstices (spaces between the striae). The elytra are highly nitid (glossy) and striae almost entirely lacking grooves. This beetle is variable in size but often large and elongate and very convex. I have seen one with a red neck (back of head) and assume it to be morio. I have not seen these except under bark. They are nocturnal and feed on large leaved eucalyptus such as manna gum. These glossy, black, nocturnal beetles feature foveau (large dints) on the pronotum, one on each side and this species also has a large crease in the elytral base directly behind these foveau. Paropsisterna morio is widespread from Tasmania to Queensland.

entry.title: Paropsisterna beata
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsisterna beata. It is a highly nitid (glossy) species and lacking striae grooves. The combined elytra have six orange dots. The orange edge of the elytra and pronotum is important to note for ID purpose to avoid possible confusion with other similar species. Several specimens were found communally under a smooth barked Eucalyptus sp. which looks similar to a manna gum. This is a nocturnal species in Victoria but also occurs in northern states and appears to be diurnal there. I have never seen it except under bark. I have observed this species also in Mt Lofty (Wonga Park, Vic), Frankston, Croydon and the Basin.

entry.title: Paropsisterna lineata
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna lineata, a mostly black and highly nitid (glossy) beetle with a few consistent yellow lines along the striae. This is a nocturnal species and found in the daytime hiding in the gaps in stringy-bark bark. I have not found it on other species of eucalyptus. I have not found it except under bark. Also seen in Croydon, Ferntree Gully, the Basin and Tasmania.

entry.title: 56 ids
entry.content: Species list for collection.

entry.title: Paropsis variolosa
entry.content: This is Paropsis variolosa. This large leaf beetle is widespread across thew Australian mainland. It is red or brown with mottles white specks. I have also seen it at Taggerty and Sydney.

entry.title: Paropsis marmorea
entry.content: Paropsis marmorea is tricky to identify. It is defined by the positioning of the three main blotches on each elytra. These three marks should be compared with the similar Paropsis geographica. To avoid confusing these two beetles, imagine a triangle joining the tree main blotches on each elytra. The line through the top two blotches runs parallel to the suture and the lateral margin of the elytra almost exactly halfway between them.

entry.title: Paropsis aegrota
entry.content: This beetle is called Paropsis geographic aegrota. The smaller dots are very variable and hardly considered in the determination of ID. The macula on the pronotum are large and open compared with geographica and colorata.

entry.title: Paropsis minor
entry.content: Paropsis minor is a small beetle with bright transverse banding of alternating black white and red. This tiny leaf beetle was found on tea tree. Many beetles benefit from good camouflage but this unexpectedly bright species seems oblivious to those supposed advantages.

entry.title: Paropsis maculata
entry.content: This bright species is Paropsis maculata. It is red with bright yellow spots, in particular two large spots behind the centre line of the beetle is very consistent. This was seen twice, the second tome in Moondarra NP. but it is more common in the northern states of NSW and Queensland. Maculata translated from Latin to 'spotted' and Paropsis means 'dish'.

entry.title: Paropsis charybdis
entry.content: This is a color variation of the variable Paropsis charybdis. It is a large beetle usually with stronger bands and red along the cheeks and the skirt.

entry.title: Paropsis augusta
entry.content: This is the montane Paropsis augusta. It is the largest species of leaf beetle that I am familiar with. The color can vary from red to yellow. The black scutellum is consistent in this species.

entry.title: Paropsis aegrota
entry.content: This is Paropsis aegrota. This leaf beetle feeds on Eucalyptus leaves. It is a large leaf beetle with several white warty blotches on each elytra. The large dot positions are improtant for identification and the smaller ones are variable.

entry.title: Paropsis charybdis
entry.content: This is Paropsis charybdis. This beetle is marble white with complex red and brown patterns. This is a widespread and very variable beetle.

entry.title: Dicranosterna spp.
entry.content: This is Dicranostera spp. A honey brown beetle with pitted elytra and pronotum feeding on blackwood acacia.

entry.title: Paropsisterna brunnea
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna brunnei, a brown leaf beetle with very smooth elytra and a black head. They usually have faint pinstripe lines along the elytra. This particular specimen is without the usual lines.

entry.title: Paropsis aspera
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsis aspera, a brown leaf beetle with the markings of an 'x' on the combined elytra. This beetle feeds on Eucalyptus as most other species also do but is anomalous as it does not fit easily into this genus.

entry.title: Paropsisterna spp.
entry.content: I have no identification suggestion for this beetle. A purple leaf beetle with yellow margins extending most of the way into the suture.

entry.title: Paropsisterna inspersa
entry.content: This beetle is a small yellow leaf beetle which seems similar to Paropsisterna variicollis. The elytral striae have a series of puncturations each with a small black dot. These were only seen in a single location. This beetle is illustrated on PaDIL from where I have derived the identification. http://bie.ala.org.au/species/Paropsisterna+inspersa#tab_gallery

entry.title: Paropsis intermedia
entry.content: A lightly mottled leaf beetle on manna gum foliage.

entry.title: Trachymela rugosa
entry.content: Trachymela are gnarled and highly textured beetles in brown colors. They are sometimes referred to as 'gumnut' leaf beetles on the presumption that they might mimic gumnuts. This beetle has sinuous ridges meandering over the elytra and with a small black dot near the forward half of the elytra.

entry.title: Paropsisterna hectica
entry.content: This beetle is the typical alpine Paropsisterna hectica. The elytra are bright green and without much variation. The beetle is locally quite common and appears to be limited to stands of snow gum.

entry.title: Paropsisterna atalanta
entry.content: This beetle is Paropsisterna atalanta. A rotund and mottled leaf beetle with its widest part towards the rear. This beetle was found on Eucalyptus. It is variable beetle and this example demonstrates the black marks that are usually present on the apex of the elytra and also at the base (forward) near the suture (centre line of the elytra). I have seen this beetle also at Frazer NP (Eildon) and Anglesea.

entry.title: Calomela ioptera
entry.content: An orange acacia leaf beetle - Calomela ioptera.

entry.title: Paropsisterna hectica
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna hectica. A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola.

entry.title: Paropsisterna hectica
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna hectica. A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola but they are green, not golden and the red flare was not noticed to occur in that population.

entry.title: Paropsisterna hectica
entry.content: A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola.

entry.title: Paropsisterna nobilitata
entry.content: The last of the tree gold and red leaf beetles with second pair of yellow blotched elongated and extending backwards and in no way outwards. This is the only species in Tasmania. It is most commonly found in Gippsland in my observation.

entry.title: Paropsisterna atalanta
entry.content: This is Paropsisterna atalanta. A rotund and mottled leaf beetle feeding on Eucalyptus in the Anglesea heathland. I have seen this in Gisborne and Eildon. It is variable with black marks on the elytra at the base or the apex.

entry.title: Paropsisterna semifumata
entry.content: Paropsisterna semifumata. This small beetle is a riparian species and feeds only on white Callistemon spp.? growing in creeks and rivers along the eastern coast of Australia up to Brisbane. I've seen it both times that I've looked at this reserve but its probably common enough along Jacksons Creek wherever you find Callistemon. Semi + fumata translates in Latin to half + smokey.

entry.title: Paropsisterna annularis
entry.content: This beetle is uniquely lacking any of the normal red pigmentation. It was found nearby a normally colored specimen which is my previous observation. The patterning of the elytra with a ring of six small marks on the apical half of the elytra is completely consistent for Paropsisterna annulus.

entry.title: Paropsisterna annularis
entry.content: A small bright leaf beetle with a complex pattern of yellow dots on a usually red background.

entry.title: Paropsisterna gloriosa
entry.content: A small but delightfully colored leaf beetle with yellow markings on red elytra.

entry.title: Peltoschema suturalis
entry.content: This is Peltoschema suturalis. This acacia leaf beetle seems to prefer broad leaf acacia and was found on Golden Wattle. This is the largest Peltoschema species that I am aware of. The name derives from the red line extending the length of the elytral suture. The species is not always green but can be yellow, as is also the case for P. orphana (fireblight beetle) and several similar species. .

entry.title: Chrysomelidae spp.
entry.content: Leaf beetle eggs are laid in characteristic arrangements that differ for each species.

entry.title: Paropsis pictipennis
entry.content: This spotty leaf beetle is called Procrisina pictipennis and is rather scarce.

entry.title: Lema bilineata
entry.content: Tobacco slug beetle (Lema bilineata) Found feeding on Brassica (canola)weeds growing in Fairfield.

entry.title: Paropsis atomaria
entry.content: This tortoise leaf beetle (Paropsis atomaria) with its red skirt, is a more colorful variation of this species.

entry.title: Paropsisterna intacta
entry.content: This leaf beetle is Paropsisterna intacta and has a pair of spare eyes on its thorax.

entry.title: Paropsis atomaria
entry.content: This common Tortoise Leaf Beetle (Paropsis atomaria)gets its name from a reptile that can also completely withdraw its feet into (under) its shell. Antennae too.
